executive_summary:
Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2023 currency.

Popcorn production facilities produce popcorn to be sold in multiple presentations. The United States is the top producer and consumer of popcorn worldwide, partly because of the growing demand for ready-to-eat popcorn. Popcorn sales have benefited from increasing per capita disposable income. However, increasingly health-conscious consumers have become wary of high-calorie and high-sodium popcorn products and of the effects microwaves have on food. The ability to adapt to changing consumer preferences by introducing healthier product lines has enabled producers to boost sales. The 2020 pandemic and resulting stay-at-home orders caused demand for snacks to rise, resulting in the largest jump in revenue growth of the decade. Rising disposable income also boosted demand for premium products, such as gourmet and organic popcorn, supporting revenue. These trends have enabled revenue to grow at an estimated CAGR of 0.6% to $2.5 billion over the five years to 2023, including a 0.2% drop in 2023 alone.

The rising price of corn over recent years also impacts popcorn prices, which partly determine revenue. Rising demand for ethanol and unfavorable weather conditions led to a jump in corn prices. Large producers with a well-established customer base can efficiently pass down cost increases to consumers, resulting in higher revenue, while smaller producers are often forced to absorb these costs, hindering profit.

Producers adapting to growing health-conscious trends by developing healthier products will be able to grow their customer base. This shows that as the industry and consumer preferences evolve, producers that are able to adapt to these changes will benefit from higher returns.

Over the coming years, popcorn revenue is likely to slow down - mainly driven by falling corn prices. Producers adjust popcorn prices according to the price of corn, so drastic drops in corn prices can lead to weakening revenue. However, rising disposable income and consumers spending more time on leisure activities will protect producers from significant losses. Producers will continue focusing on new product development to adapt to changing consumer preferences, creating new opportunities in the industry. These trends will cause revenue to inch upward at an estimated CAGR of 0.1% to $2.5 billion over the five years to 2028.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Popcorn producers' revenue has been rising at a CAGR of 0.6% to $2.5 billion over the five years to 2023
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Including an estimated 0.2% decline in 2023 alone. Profit is set to reach 3.1% in 2023.

Consumers were required to spend more time at home during the pandemic, boosting demand for food and snacks, causing popcorn production to expand. Snacks are often considered discretionary products - when disposable income rises, consumers are inclined to purchase more snacks, boosting demand for popcorn. Similarly, when consumers spend less time in leisure activities, demand for popcorn products weakens, as popcorn is commonly consumed while watching movies, sporting events and gatherings. High inflation over recent years has caused popcorn sales to slow down as consumers lower discretionary spending.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Health Trends Drive Demand for Popcorn
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers in the United States have become increasingly health-conscious, causing demand for sugary snacks to drop and boosting popcorn sales. Many health professionals and consumers recommend popcorn as a healthier snack alternative as it is often lower in carbohydrates, sodium and fat. This trend has pushed producers to adjust their product mixes to adapt to shifting health trends by introducing and marketing products with lower sodium and fat content. Smaller companies have benefited even more by focusing specifically on healthier, ready-to-eat popcorn products.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Corn Price Volatility Harms Smaller Producers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Since corn is the main input in popcorn production, corn prices directly impact retail prices, influencing sales.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Popcorn producers' revenue is expected to rise at a CAGR of 0.1% to $2.5 billion over the five years to 2028, as profit is projected to reach 3.5%.
Improving Economic Conditions Support Demand for Discretionary Products
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As inflation continues to slow down, disposable income is likely to expand. This will enable consumers to spend more on popcorn, which is rarely considered necessary. Consumers will spend more time on leisure activities in the coming years, boosting demand for snacks. Although both of these factors are on the rise, they will not be able to cause the industry to expand significantly.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Producers Benefit From Adapting to Consumer Preferences
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumers will continue to become more health conscious, causing demand for popcorn to continue expanding. Popcorn producers will continue developing healthy products to diversify their product mixes. Producers will also continue developing new flavors to capture new markets, particularly gourmet flavors (e.g. chocolate and other sweetened varieties). Producers will promote healthy eating through marketing initiatives that compare popcorn with other unhealthy snacks, such as chips. This aims to switch consumer preferences to favor popcorn.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Dropping Corn Prices Prevent Significant Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Changes in demand for ethanol make it difficult to forecast future corn prices, although they are likely to drop. Falling prices cause popcorn prices to weaken, resulting in lower revenue growth. However, lower product prices can promote popcorn consumption, boosting demand.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry produce popcorn, including ready-to-eat popcorn, microwaveable popcorn and other consumer packages of unpopped popcorn.

negative_impact_factors: Time spent on leisure and sports

threats: Time spent on leisure and sports

key_trends: Volatility in the price of corn has had a significant effect on industry operators
With structural and product change, the industry has grown to fulfill higher demand
Competition among popcorn producers will further intensify
Popcorn producers will continue developing healthy products to diversify product mixes

market_segmentation.segment_description: Retailers, which are the largest market for popcorn, include supermarket chains, grocery stores, convenience stores and drug stores.
Retailers, which are the largest market for popcorn, include supermarket chains, grocery stores, convenience stores and drug stores.
Retailers, which are the largest market for popcorn, include supermarket chains, grocery stores, convenience stores and drug stores.
Wholesalers purchase popcorn from manufacturers to then resell it to other downstream markets, including supermarkets, convenience stores and other retailers with bulk, packaged popcorn.

products_and_services.product_description: Unpopped popcorn can be sold in microwavable packaging or as kernels that consumers can pop at home.
Ready-to-eat popcorn is pre-popped and is often made with coatings and flavorings before being packaged into consumer bags and containers.

tier_1_suppliers: Laminated Plastics Manufacturing in the US
Corn, Wheat & Soybean Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Paper Bag & Disposable Plastic Product Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Supermarkets & Grocery Stores in the US
tier_2_buyers: Warehouse Clubs & Supercenters in the US
Cookie, Cracker & Pasta Production in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Many factors determine popcorn sales. Most demand comes from wholesalers and retail supermarkets. When consumers demand more popcorn at supermarkets and grocery stores, these markets will purchase more popcorn, boosting revenue.
Producers are sensitive to the price of corn. Corn is subject to fluctuations due to unpredictable factors such as weather, domestic and foreign government farm programs and changes in global demand.
Perceptions of healthy eating in the United States also affect popcorn sales. Demand for distinct products changes with consumer views on health.

international_trade_points.trade_description: The United States is the world's largest producer and consumer of popcorn, causing domestic production to satisfy a large majority of domestic demand.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports Stay Regional, Though New Avenues Widen
international_trade_points.trade_description: Most imports come from Canada, which shares borders and a favorable trade agreement with the United States. Imports from Asia, specifically Taiwan, have increased, mainly due to the low cost of production in these countries.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Export Activity Does Not Affect Popcorn Producers
international_trade_points.trade_description: The industry stopped exporting popcorn after 2003. Popcorn producers don't sell products abroad.

business_locations.location_description: The Plains are a common place for food and snack producers to base operations, providing producers with easy access to corn farms.
Similar to the Plains, there are multiple corn farms based in the Great Lakes, attracting more popcorn producers.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The NLEA requires producers to have accurate nutrition labels with nutrient content claims and proper health messages or warnings for things including allergies or carcinogens. Any claims are evaluated by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) before being approved. Failure to abide by these rules can destroy a producer's credibility.

The CAA requires compliance with air quality standards and empowers the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to establish and enforce limits on the emission of pollutants. The CAA establishes regulations for sulfur and nitrogen oxides and strict requirements for ozone emissions and other toxic materials.

The CWA regulates the discharge of pollutants into surface water. The CWA establishes a system of minimum national efficiency standards on an industry-to-industry basis, in addition to water quality standards and a discharge permit program.

Manufacturers have to ensure the safety of workers, mainly through noise and dust standards. Similarly, OSHA requires manufacturers to provide proper training on the use of machinery and procedure to reduce workplace risks.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The popcorn production industry is mature.
The level of industry assistance is low and steady.
The regulation level is heavy and steady.

basis_points.basis_description: Popcorn producers encounter much internal competition, with much of it centered on flavoring and packaging.
Companies that offer ready-to-eat popcorn will become more competitive because of the growing consumer preference for this product.
Producers also compete on price and consumer loyalty.
Snyder's-Lance has been able to maintain its market share because of its well-branded products that consumers continue to buy.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Consumers with strong brand preferences are often unlikely to purchase other brands.
Companies that have become household staples generate more revenue.
These companies have been able to capture a significant share of the market, although they continue to compete with smaller brands.

As the industry continues to grow, consumers will try new popcorn brands, preventing larger companies from expanding rapidly. Producers often opt for consolidation to expand their market share and product offering by offering new flavors that attract new consumers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Volatile Input Prices Lead to High Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Volatility in corn, sweetener and oil prices have caused purchase costs to fluctuate. This is mainly the result of significant supply chain disruptions and changing environmental conditions.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: R&D Capabilities Call for Higher Wages
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The rising demand for popcorn has caused the industry to grow and producers to expand operations, resulting in a higher need for skilled workers. Large companies have also increased spending on R&D capabilities as they rely on scientists to develop new flavors and kernels.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Other Costs Expand as Producers Develop New Products
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Companies increasingly invest in the development of new flavors to adapt to changing consumer preferences, boosting R&D spending. Similarly, large companies aim to develop the ideal genetically modified kernel for popcorn production. This results in higher spending on research capabilities and causes other costs to expand.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Popcorn production requires a moderate level of capital investment. Modern manufacturing plants require sophisticated technology and equipment to increase productivity without the need for additional labor. Average companies spend an estimated 2.0% of revenue on depreciation costs.

Capital intensity varies considerably with the size of the producer. Small- and medium-size facilities will have a lower capital-to-labor ratio because they lack the resources to invest in expensive technology and equipment, resulting in higher reliance on labor. Meanwhile, technological innovation in machinery and equipment has remained relatively stagnant, causing capital intensity to inch downward over recent years.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Volatile Input Prices Impact Popcorn Producers
volatility_points.volatility_description: The price of corn and oil is directly impacted by multiple factors, including weather conditions and the supply and demand for these products. Significant supply chain disruptions and changing environmental conditions have caused input prices to skyrocket over recent years, boosting revenue volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Economic Conditions and Consumer Preferences Affect Sales
volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand for snacks rose during the pandemic as consumers spent more time at home, boosting popcorn sales. Popcorn is often lower in carbohydrates and sodium, making it a healthier snack alternative and attracting more health-conscious consumers. Since popcorn is often considered a discretionary product, higher disposable income for consumers raises demand for popcorn, boosting revenue.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Popcorn goes through a specific process before being sold. First, producers must choose the correct type of corn since of the four commonly known types of corn, only one pops. This corn is referred to as popcorn and is a specific type of flint corn. Varieties of popcorn are grown to pop into two distinctive shapes: snowflake, which is the larger popcorn, and mushroom, the smaller variety used in popcorn candies and snacks.

Major popcorn producers, such as Conagra Brands, employ a team of scientists to genetically modify and pollinate their hybrid corn by hand. Selecting the best variety or hybrid of popcorn to be grown and processed is critical to producing high-quality raw materials for making popcorn. These kernels are then used as seeds to grow corn that will be harvested and sold. As many as 30,000 new hybrids per year are created to improve popcorn.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in a niche or do you produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: We diversify our product portfolio by adding specific flavors and emphasizing the quality and healthy aspects of popcorn. Usually, we only produce unpopped and popped popcorn products.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by imports?
FAQs.answer: Since the United States is the biggest producer and consumer of popcorn in the world, imports are not a main concern. US consumers usually demand domestic popcorn products.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: We have been exposed to a moderate level of revenue volatility due to the high volatility of the input prices, which in this case are corn and oil prices.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing heavily in R&D to meet changing consumer preferences?
FAQs.answer: Health-consciousness trends have been increasing in recent years. It is important to conduct the proper R&D to satisfy demand for more healthy and high-quality products.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Automation has largely restrained the increase in wage cost over the past five years. However, labor is still necessary to operate the machinery.

FAQs.question: Does your company invest heavily in capital?
FAQs.answer: We invest heavily in capital in order to have the most efficient manufacturing plants to increase productivity without needing additional labor.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Due to the highly regulated nature of this industry, we always need to be on top of new and updated health and safety requirements.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to comply with new environmental standards?
FAQs.answer: As environmental standards keep increasing, we focus on clean technologies and pollution prevention principles to help the environment and improve product quality.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: The price of corn has declined during the past 12 months, benefiting industry margins.

FAQs.question: How has your company adapted to the increasing prices of key inputs over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: If input prices increase, we are able to pass down the cost to customers by increasing the price of our products and able to increase revenue. However, if the price is too volatile, profit margins could decline.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to pass on cost increases? Are you located in key market areas where members can afford higher fees?
FAQs.answer: Since the price of corn can fluctuate significantly, producers' ability to pass on unexpected cost increases down the supply chain is vital to maintaining profitability.

FAQs.question: Do you have large contracts in comparison with your competitors? What do you do to attract and maintain sizable orders?
FAQs.answer: Successful producers have reliable contracts with suppliers of corn to considerably reduce supply volatility. Guaranteed supplies at fixed prices minimize supply costs and aid production planning.

FAQs.question: Are you able to leverage economies of scale? What is your budget for expanding operations?
FAQs.answer: In general, larger operators are able to benefit from economies of scale; they can lower per-unit costs by spreading total costs over a larger volume of products to maintain profit.

FAQs.question: How closely do you monitor trends in per capita time spent on leisure and sports? How do you cope with decreases in leisure time?
FAQs.answer: Many leisure activities such as watching TV or entertaining guests are often coupled with snacks including popcorn.
